Title: Retrograde transport of D-[3H]-aspartate injected into the monkey amygdaloid complex
Abstract: The possibility that certain of the afferents of the primate amygdaloid complex use an excitatory amino acid transmitter was evaluated by injecting D-[3H]-aspartate into the amygdala of two Macaca fascicularis monkeys. The distribution of D-[3H]-aspartate labeled neurons was compared with those labeled with the nonselective retrograde tracer WGA- HRP injected at the same location as the isotope. Retrogradely labeled cells of both types were observed in a variety of cortical and subcortical structures observed in a variety of cortical and subcortical structures and in discrete regions within the amygdala. D- [3H]-aspartate labeled neurons were observed in layers III and V of the frontal, cingulate, insular and temporal cortices. In the hippocampal formation, heavily labeled cells were observed in the CA1 region and in the deep layers of the entorhinal cortex. Of the subcortical afferents, the claustrum and the midbrain peripeduncular nucleus contained the greatest number of D-[3H]-aspartate labeled cells. Subcortical afferents that are not thought to use excitatory amino acids, such as the cholinergic neurons of the basal nucleus of Meynert, did not retrogradely transport the isotope. Within the amygdala, the most conspicuous labeling was in the paralaminar nucleus which forms the rostral and ventral limits of the amygdala. When the D-[3H]-aspartate injection involved the basal nucleus, many labeled cells were also observed in the lateral nucleus. Retrograde transport of D-[3H]- aspartate injected into the amygdala, therefore, appears to demonstrate a subpopulation of inputs that may use an excitatory amino acid transmitter

@Methods.Comments:
In case M-1-87 D-[3H]-aspartate is combined with WGA-HRP, whereas in case M-3-88 D-[3H]-aspartate is not combined with any other tracer substance.
Further: " We have used bilateral injections to conserve on the number of animals used in this project. In previous experiments in which retrograde tracers were placed in the amygdala of one side, we have noted a small number of retrogradely labeled cells on the contralateral side. However, the number was extremely small and would not alter the topographic distribution indicated by the much larger number of ipsilaterally labeled cells." (p. 376)

@Injections.Citation:
"In order to compare the distribution of cells selectively labeled with D-[3H]-aspartate with all possible afferent sources to the injection site, a solution containing the nospecific retrograde tracer, wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) in combination with D-[3H]-aspartate (the non-metabolized form of aspartate) was injected into the amygdala of one animal (M1-87). ...On the left side, an injection of approximately 200 nl of the comnbined tracer solution was aimed at the basal nucleus and on the right side, an injection of approximately 300 nl was aimed at the lateral nucleus." (p. 376)
"In experiment M-1-87, the combined injections of WGA-HRP and D-[3H]-aspartate heavily involved the amygdala bilaterally. The smaller injection was located on the left side and was focused in the magnocellular and intermediate divisions of the basal nucleus (Fig. 1, A and B). ...we will refer to this as the "basal nucleus injection".
The larger injection in experiment M-1-87 was on the right side of the brain and was focused in the lateral nucleus. In the D-[3H]-aspartate preparation, the injection was confined within the amygdala and was limited laterally by fibers of the external capsule that form the lateral surface of the amygdala. The lateral aspect of the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus was also labeled by the injection. The WGA-HRP injection again appeared somewhat more extensive and, in addition to the involvement of the lateral nucleus, also heavily involved the lateral aspect of the basal nucleus. There was also some diffusion laterally into the adjacent white matter and dorsally into the substantia innominata. We will refer to this as the 'lateral nucleus injection'. " (p. 378)

"In order to compare the distribution of cells selectively labeled with D-[3H]-aspartate with all possible afferent sources to the injection site, a solution containing the nospecific retrograde tracer, wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) in combination with D-[3H]-aspartate (the non-metabolized form of aspartate) was injected into the amygdala of one animal (M1-87). ...On the left side, an injection of approximately 200 nl of the comnbined tracer solution was aimed at the basal nucleus and on the right side, an injection of approximately 300 nl was aimed at the lateral nucleus." (p. 376)
"In experiment M-1-87, the combined injections of WGA-HRP and D-[3H]-aspartate heavily involved the amygdala bilaterally. The smaller injection was located on the left side and was focused in the magnocellular and intermediate divisions of the basal nucleus (Fig. 1, A and B). There was a diffuse deposition of silver grains over the most medial aspect of the lateral nucleus and the lateral aspect of the accessory basal nucleus. ...we will refer to this as the "basal nucleus injection".
The larger injection in experiment M-1-87 was on the right side of the brain and was focused in the lateral nucleus. In the D-[3H]-aspartate preparation, the injection was confined within the amygdala and was limited laterally by fibers of the external capsule that form the lateral surface of the amygdala. The lateral aspect of the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus was also labeled by the injection. The WGA-HRP injection again appeared somewhat more extensive and, in addition to the involvement of the lateral nucleus, also heavily involved the lateral aspect of the basal nucleus. There was also some diffusion laterally into the adjacent white matter and dorsally into the substantia innominata. We will refer to this as the 'lateral nucleus injection'. " (p. 378)

However, the number was extremely small and would not alter the topographic distribution indicated by the much larger number of ipsilaterally labeled cells." (p. 376)

There was a diffuse deposition of silver grains over the most medial aspect of the lateral nucleus and the lateral aspect of the accessory basal nucleus. ...we will refer to this as the "basal nucleus injection".
The larger injection in experiment M-1-87 was on the right side of the brain and was focused in the lateral nucleus. "In order to compare the distribution of cells selectively labeled with D-[3H]-aspartate with all possible afferent sources to the injection site, a solution containing the nonspecific retrograde tracer wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) in combination with D-[3H]-aspartate (the non-metabolized form of aspartate) was injected into the amygdala of one animal (M1-87). ...On the left side, an injection of approximately 200 nl of the comnbined tracer solution was aimed at the basal nucleus and on the right side, an injection of approximately 300 nl was aimed at the lateral nucleus." (p. 376)
"In experiment M-1-87, the combined injections of WGA-HRP and D-[3H]-aspartate heavily involved the amygdala bilaterally. The smaller injection was located on the left side and was focused in the magnocellular and intermediate divisions of the basal nucleus (Fig. 1, A and B). There was a diffuse deposition of silver grains over the most medial aspect of the lateral nucleus and the lateral aspect of the accessory basal nucleus. ...we will refer to this as the "basal nucleus injection".
The larger injection in experiment M-1-87 was on the right side of the brain and was focused in the lateral nucleus. In the D-[3H]-aspartate preparation, the injection was confined within the amygdala and was limited laterally by fibers of the external capsule that form the lateral surface of the amygdala. The lateral aspect of the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus was also labeled by the injection. The WGA-HRP injection again appeared somewhat more extensive and, in addition to the involvement of the lateral nucleus, also heavily involved the lateral aspect of the basal nucleus. There was also some diffusion laterally into the adjacent white matter and dorsally into the substantia innominata. We will refer to this as the 'lateral nucleus injection'. " (p. 378)

"In a second animal (M-3-88), smaller injections of D-[3-H] aspartate alone were made into the amygdala. In this case, a 50 nl injection of the tracer was aimed at the dorsal or magnocellular division of the basal nucleus on the right side and the same volume was aimed at the more ventrally situated, intermediate and parvicellular divisions of the basal nucleus on the left side." (p. 376)
"In experimentM-3-88, both injections of D-[3H]-aspartate were small and completely confined to the amygdala. The injection on th eright side (Fig. 1C and D) was focused within the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus (Bmg) whereas the injection on the left side was located at a mid dorsoventral position within the basal nucleus in the intermediate division (Bi). We will refer to these as the Bmg and Bi injections respectively." (p. 378)

"In a second animal (M-3-88), smaller injections of D-[3-H] aspartate alone were made into the amygdala. In this case, a 50 nl injection of the tracer was aimed at the dorsal or magnocellular division of the basal nucleus on the right side and the same volume was aimed at the more ventrally situated, intermediate and parvicellular divisions of the basal nucleus on the left side." (p. 376)
"In experimentM-3-88, both injections of D-[3H]-aspartate were small and completely confined to the amygdala. The injection on th eright side (Fig. 1C and D) was focused within the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus (Bmg) whereas the injection on the left side was located at a mid dorsoventral position within the basal nucleus in the intermediate division (Bi). We will refer to these as the Bmg and Bi injections respectively." (p. 378)

publication.title: Retrograde transport of D-[3H]-aspartate injected into the monkey amygdaloid complex
publication.abstract: The possibility that certain of the afferents of the primate amygdaloid complex use an excitatory amino acid transmitter was evaluated by injecting D-[3H]-aspartate into the amygdala of two Macaca fascicularis monkeys. The distribution of D-[3H]-aspartate labeled neurons was compared with those labeled with the nonselective retrograde tracer WGA- HRP injected at the same location as the isotope. Retrogradely labeled cells of both types were observed in a variety of cortical and subcortical structures observed in a variety of cortical and subcortical structures and in discrete regions within the amygdala. D- [3H]-aspartate labeled neurons were observed in layers III and V of the frontal, cingulate, insular and temporal cortices. In the hippocampal formation, heavily labeled cells were observed in the CA1 region and in the deep layers of the entorhinal cortex. Of the subcortical afferents, the claustrum and the midbrain peripeduncular nucleus contained the greatest number of D-[3H]-aspartate labeled cells. Subcortical afferents that are not thought to use excitatory amino acids, such as the cholinergic neurons of the basal nucleus of Meynert, did not retrogradely transport the isotope. Within the amygdala, the most conspicuous labeling was in the paralaminar nucleus which forms the rostral and ventral limits of the amygdala. When the D-[3H]-aspartate injection involved the basal nucleus, many labeled cells were also observed in the lateral nucleus. Retrograde transport of D-[3H]- aspartate injected into the amygdala, therefore, appears to demonstrate a subpopulation of inputs that may use an excitatory amino acid transmitter
